newsitem.title: INDIA: CRICKET-INDIA ORDERS INQUIRY INTO MATCH-FIXING CLAIMS.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-INDIA ORDERS INQUIRY INTO MATCH-FIXING CLAIMS.

text.p: The Indian cricket board on Saturday ordered an inquiry into allegations of match-fixing and betting.
The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) secretary Jagmohan Dalmiya told reporters former Supreme Court Chief Justice Y.V. Chandrachud would probe the allegations.
Among claims to be examined is one by former test player Manoj Prabhakar that he was offered money to "throw" a match three years ago.
Dalmiya, who has taken over as the International Cricket Council (ICC) president, steps down as BCCI secretary on July 1.

"It is expected that everyone will extend co-operation for proper conduct of the inquiry considering the seriousness of the charges and in the interest of the country," he said. "The BCCI will not spare anyone found guilty of match-fixing.
"But if the allegations are not proved, the Board will take appropriate action against those responsible for spreading such malicious and motivated rumours to tarnish the image of Indian cricket."

Prabhakar recently told India's Outlook magazine that he was offered 2.5 million Indian rupees ($70,000) by a teammate to sabotage a match in favour of Pakistan during the Singer Cup limited-over series in Sri Lanka in 1994.
Former Indian team manager Ajit Wadekar issued a statement saying that he had kept a watch on the cricketers but found nothing to substantiate allegations of bribery and involvement with bookmakers.
